children.subject: Thank you! Do you know personally of any research programs I can look into?

Here are a few links you could check out:

http://urap.berkeley.edu/

http://beehive.berkeley.edu/

https://www.nsf.gov/crssprgm/reu/list_result.jsp?unitid=5049 (NSF REU, do research at other schools over the summer)

https://eecs.berkeley.edu/research

Personally I've had more success keeping an eye out for grad students advertising that they are looking for help, or contacting professors who do research that you are interested in. Since you mention that you want to go into teaching, you may find this research area interesting: https://www2.eecs.berkeley.edu/Research/Areas/EDUC/

The department also holds info sessions on getting undergraduate research and I found these to be quite useful when I started thinking about doing research, I recommend looking for those in the department emails. I'm not sure when the next one will be!
Thank you! This is really helpful. I'll look into it.

Sorry to keep bothering everyone about this, but does it matter if you receive a low grade in a nontechnical course. I've got every variation of a B in CS and Math courses, each time I got progressively better, but got ONE really low score in some Science Fiction course. It killed my current GPA. Does that matter at all?

Getting accepted to the PhD program here at Cal, particular for CS as I have been told by a professor, is extremely difficult. If your GPA is somewhere near 3.0, you would really need some good letters of recommendation/research experience. Given this, definitely try to get involved with some research as soon as you can.

Oh I see, the GPA cutoff you were talking about was the one for the PhD application! I have been told by the staff that reviews grad applications, that recommendation letters usually hold a bigger weight than the GPA (though GPA is still very important).

Find a professor (or two) that shares your enthusiasm and interests in CS. Go talk to them about your aspirations, ask if they have any advise. If you haven't taken that many classes yet, thats even better! You have every reason to ask them low level questions. No question is dumb! (If there was a dumb question to be asked, I guarantee that they have heard it.) Just try to create a relationship with them such that you can go to them and ask them questions about your class schedule, research, clubs, etc. These relationships will slowly turn into recommendation letters. 

I personally had a rough time doing this, and I started very late in the game. If I could do it again, I would start as soon as possible. Good luck!!

Thank you! I'm really worried about the recommendation letters. I don't just want to walk up to a professors after taking their class for less than a semester and asking them. I'm interested in graphics and theory so Dan Garcia and Jonathan Shewchuk (hope I spelled his name right) are on the list of eligible bachelors. Any advice on how to approach them, especially since neither of them are my professor this year?

Try emailing them first to set up a time to meet and to see if they are on campus this semester. Or try looking them up on the EECS website--their office hours should be on there. Just start by taking to them. Try to get a feel for if you feel comfortable around them. I would constantly cop-out for the "Can you tell me about what you are researching in?" and then asking questions about anything they said that sounded foreign to me. Professors do not expect you to know what they are taking about, but they will try to connect it to any classes you have taken so far. Another thing you could ask is "I am interested in ___, can you tell me more about the field? ...What is the coolest thing you have seen?" etc. If you want to try talking to professors that are teach a class you are currently taking, I used, "I just wanted to introduce myself so that I wont feel intimidated to talk to you when the class starts to pick up" Hopefully that helps!!

To the instructor above, I started in Fall of 2016. I know about the GPA cutoff for the undergraduate major, but I was under the impression that I could still apply for the PhD without an undergraduate major in CS.

history.content:
Hi, 

I'm an intended CS major at Berkeley and this is my second year, third semester. I started thinking about graduate school over the summer and I REALLY want to go here to do it and get my PhD, regardless of whether or not I make the major (my backup is applied mathematics). I'm working on getting my GPA up so I can qualify for the 3.0 minimum. I want to get my PhD with hopes that one day I'll be able to teach because I really am in love with CS all together, but I need some advice. 

I have one specific question, but once that's answered I'm open to any random suggestions. 

1. Is the GPA cap fixed? I know I have plenty of time to raise my GPA but on the off chance(very off chance) I get a 2.99... Will my application get thrown away?

Also, you guys should know I plan to do research/internships for these remaining two summers before I have to apply. Okay, officially open to suggestions. Any ideas?
